title: 110_s3329
content:
The "Compensation and Respect for Energy Workers Act of 2008" or the "CARE Act" expands the list of cancers eligible for compensation under existing programs. Section 4(b)(2) of the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act is amended to include additional diseases for compensation, such as chronic lymphocytic leukemia, posterior subcapsular cataracts, nonmalignant thyroid nodular disease, and malignant tumors of the brain and central nervous system. The list of eligible cancers for compensation is expanded under the "Compensation and Respect for Energy Workers Act of 2008" or the "CARE Act". The Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act of 2000 is amended to include lists of qualified physicians for medical and impairment screenings selected by independent medical associations or institutions of higher education. The Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act of 2000 is amended to include notice to claimants on available benefits for which they may be eligible under the Act. SEC. 4 of the Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act of 2000 is amended to include trade names of chemicals in site profiles and provide public access to these profiles and related information. SEC. 5 amends Section 3672 of the Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act of 2000 to specify payment of compensation to survivors and estates of contractor employees. The Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act of 2000, Section 3672, specifies payment of compensation to survivors and estates of contractor employees under this subtitle. If a covered DOE contractor employee dies before receiving compensation, the amount they would have received will be paid to a survivor or the employee's estate. The Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act of 2000, Section 3672, states that survivors of covered DOE contractor employees are eligible for compensation under this subtitle. Survivors can choose between contractor employee compensation or survivor compensation, but not both. Expansion of authority of Ombudsman of Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program. The Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act of 2000 is amended to specify the duties of the Office, including assisting individuals with claims, providing information on benefits, acting as an advocate, and recommending locations for resource centers. The Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act of 2000 is amended to specify the duties of the Office, including contracting for services with expertise in health physics, medicine, industrial hygiene, and toxicology. SEC. 7. Extension of time for claimants to respond to requests for information: Individuals filing claims under the Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act of 2000 will have a minimum of 120 days to respond to information requests from the Secretary of Labor.

SEC. 8. Extension of statute of limitations for judicial review of contractor employee claims. Section 9 of the Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act of 2000 addresses payment for transportation expenses and personal care services. The amendment in subsection (a) extends the timeframe for final decisions by the Secretary of Labor to 1 year instead of 60 days. This change applies to decisions issued after the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Labor must regulate direct payments to providers for personal care services and transportation expenses for individuals under the Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act of 2000 within 90 days of the Act's enactment. An individual who receives medical benefits under the Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act of 2000. SEC. 10. ENHANCEMENT OF TRANSPARENCY IN CLAIMS PROCESS. The President must ensure that denial notifications and correspondence regarding claims under the Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act of 2000 are written clearly and accompanied by reasons for denial and information on how to potentially get the claim approved. Additionally, regulations must be established for document retention within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Labor and the Secretary of Energy must establish regulations within 90 days to retain original documents related to Department of Energy facilities for potential compensation claims under the Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act of 2000. Employees must have access to these documents.
